Description: Limestone statuette of ram-headed Amun-Re. The Egyptian ram-headed deity Amun-Re, seated in a high-backed chair, the top broken away. He wears a wig with long lappets falling in front of the shoulder, and a long chiton tied at the waist, with curved-up lower edge. Over the chiton is an overfold which falls in flaps on each side, of the waist. The feet are bare and rest on a plinth. The hands lie along the rails of the chair. Rough work, but Greek in treatment.
Curator's comments: Images of a ram-headed god lying lying on a ram's back or sitting on a throne supported by a ram are common on Cyprus between around 600 and 300 BC. They are usually interepreted as images of Zeus Ammon, a cult that developed in Lybya (especially Cyrene), or Baal Hammon the tutelary god of Carthage (Buchholz 1991; Coenaerts and Samaes 2006; Counts 2008; Karageorghis 1988; Kleibel 2007; Sophocleous 1985,.58-69).
